Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Antioxidant Therapy in the Perinatal Period

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured through sealed envelopes

Participants.evidence: pregnant women aged 18-40 years with gestational ages between 20-28 weeks, at risk of oxidative stress-related complications

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received antioxidant therapy, while the control group received a placebo

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the impact of antioxidant therapy on reducing oxidative stress-related complications during the perinatal period

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of preterm birth, assessed until delivery

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: randomised using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured through sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted using an intention-to-treat approach, with 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group demonstrated a significant reduction in preterm birth rates compared to the control group (mean difference = 10%, 95% CI 5% to 15%; p = 0.01)

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, occurring in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Institutes of Health
